Vast: The Crystal Caverns - Second Printing with Miniatures

Help us print the second run of Vast: The Crystal Caverns.
Pre-Order!
Created by
Patrick Leder
Patrick Leder
5,711 backers pledged $499,030 to help bring this project to life.
Rewards Campaign FAQ Updates 12 Comments 2,375 Community
Share this project
Saved

Use this space to cheer the creator along, ask questions, and talk to your fellow backers. Please remember to be respectful and considerate. Thanks!

Only backers can post comments. If you have a question, ask the project creator.

    36. Jussi-Pekka Jokinen on February 5

      @Luke: The rulebook goes through all the role combinations for each player count, and gives suggestions on what roles to use for the first game. For a 3-player game, the first game should be played with Knight vs. Goblins vs. Dragon OR Knight vs. Goblins vs. Cave. Hope this helps. :)

    37. Nithrock on February 5

      @luke I haven't played with 3 yet, but I would probably suggest Knight, dragon and goblins, as the cave can autopilot itself - but I believe the others require rules variations if removed.

    38. bigwoof on February 5

      just filled up my pledge! looking forward to getting this! :-)

    39. Luke on February 4

      @Nithrock and @Lance, that is great advice thanks.

      Has anyone had experience with three and would recommend any set ups for vast newbies?

    40. Nithrock on February 4

      @luke and @lance I would suggest starting with 4 and play the 4 main roles (not the theif). And if possible play 4 games with the same 4 people where everyone gets to play each role.

      Definitely agree with lance though, assign/pick roles in advance and have everyone read the rules.
      My reasoning for the main 4 (and playing with 4 and not 5) is that with the main 4 the roles are clear, and the intent is clear. So everyone has a grasp of how they interact with everyone else and who they are trying to beat. With the theif, he kind of does his own thing that is separate, and whilst the cave also does its own thing that is separate, it balances out the others, and keeps a bit more of a check on the game (it is trying to stall everyone until the point it can collapse, where the theif is running around doing its own disjointed thing - which is fine when everyone knows what they are doing, but for learning it felt too detached and easy to lose track of what the theif was doing - and it was hard to guage how the theif was going in terms of winning).

    41. Lance on February 4

      @luke i suggest that you assign each role to a player before hand and let them read the rules of their role before hand! basically prepare them a bit or else you will have to "waste" about half an hour explaining all the roles!

      I didn't have any problem at all starting with 5 players and i picked the thief since it's recommended that a newbie shouldn't use this role... i won by a really close margin the dragon was one tile away to win and th egoblin could manage to kill the knight in their next turn if i didn't manage to carry my last treasure! the cave also was at 3 crystals so high chance he could have won too!

      but if you are less than 5 i guess you should actually remove the cave! by far it seems the most complicate role to play actively

    42. Steven Becker on February 4

    50. Luke on February 3

      Getting myself super excited to play some Vast very soon! I thought this would be a good place to discuss how to play the game.

      Not in that way...let me explain...

      Because of the interconnecting ruleset, asymmetrical nature of the roles. I have found that those first few game sessions will be the most important sessions to secure the games future in getting it to the table. I have noticed with reviews on BGG that some people find some combinations and roles work better/ seem more balanced than others.

      A great discussion on this is found here, with a survey of optimal combinations https://boardgamegeek.com/thread/1626776/red-player-one-reviews-vast-crystal-caverns

      It seems clear that learning the rules is very important as it really can risk the harmonious balance of the roles and can sour some of your player groups experiences. Duly noted.

      Aside from this, I was hoping if people who own the game could give any insight or tips to help make those first few games really go great. Whether its something like "cool as it sounds, don't give the cave role to a novice player that likes to do loads of stuff on their turn" or "Your take that cut throat loving players should pick this role" to "make sure you remember this rule, as you can break the game" stuff like that.

      I think I speak for all of those getting the game (or any game in fact) that its important that all players have a great first impression. No one wants their new game stuck in cupboard jail.

      For those having backerkit issues, hope this doesn't get in the way and that you get your issues all sorted out!

      I'm super happy that Patrick is so dedicated to the game, he is always involved with forums and trying to help people get the most of the game. And want to take this opportunity to thank him, this is such a unique game that it excites as much as it does terrify even the most seasoned board gamers. Thanks Patrick!
